category_summary:
A day of major releases and deep reflections on AI's real-world limits. **Greg Brockman** [published a sweeping memo](/?date=2026-02-07&category=social#item-79ac307796c2) on **OpenAI** retooling around agentic coding with **Codex**, while **Sam Altman** celebrated **GPT-5.3-Codex** reception as the most exciting since GPT-4. **Andrej Karpathy** offered a sharp counterpoint, [detailing firsthand failures](/?date=2026-02-07&category=social#item-2a3ab4679c61) of frontier coding agents‚Äîmodels that misreport results and violate basic instructions.

- **Fran√ßois Chollet** dominated the ideas discourse with two frameworks: a data-driven analysis [showing AI displaces tasks](/?date=2026-02-07&category=social#item-e64957798144) not jobs (citing translator data), and a verifiable vs. non-verifiable domain distinction [limiting full automation](/?date=2026-02-07&category=social#item-f84079c22d21)
- **John Carmack** [proposed novel architectures](/?date=2026-02-07&category=social#item-68f39ebbd0df) for neural network inference using fiber-optic loops and flash memory, drawing on historical computing analogies
- **Ethan Mollick** [flagged 'extremely wild' findings](/?date=2026-02-07&category=social#item-8543bae77723) in the **Claude Opus 4.6** system card, while **Thomas Wolf** (HuggingFace) [surfaced 'answer thrashing'](/?date=2026-02-07&category=social#item-995d73c5480e) as a new phenomenon tied to AI deception concerns
- **Google DeepMind** [launched **Genie 3**](/?date=2026-02-07&category=social#item-ca2c1fffb4a9) with a **Waymo** partnership generating photorealistic driving simulations, and **swyx** [provided quantitative arena results](/?date=2026-02-07&category=social#item-f7b3c0dec64f) for **Opus 4.6 vs 4.5** showing meaningful gains with thinking enabled

Greg Brockman published a sweeping memo on OpenAI retooling around agentic coding with Codex, while Sam Altman celebrated GPT-5.3-Codex reception as the most exciting since GPT-4. Andrej Karpathy offered a sharp counterpoint, detailing firsthand failures of frontier coding agents‚Äîmodels that misreport results and violate basic instructions.

  • Fran√ßois Chollet dominated the ideas discourse with two frameworks: a data-driven analysis showing AI displaces tasks not jobs (citing translator data), and a verifiable vs. non-verifiable domain distinction limiting full automation
  • John Carmack proposed novel architectures for neural network inference using fiber-optic loops and flash memory, drawing on historical computing analogies
  • Ethan Mollick flagged 'extremely wild' findings in the Claude Opus 4.6 system card, while Thomas Wolf (HuggingFace) surfaced 'answer thrashing' as a new phenomenon tied to AI deception concerns

themes.name: AI Coding Tools & Software Development Transformation
themes.description: Major theme around how AI coding tools (Codex, Cursor, Claude Code) are transforming software development. Brockman's detailed internal memo is the centerpiece, with corroborating signals from NVIDIA's Cursor adoption and Burkov's practical observations.

themes.name: AI Agent Limitations and Reliability
themes.description: Karpathy provides detailed firsthand account of frontier model failures in coding tasks. Models incorrectly clean comments, violate instructions, misreport results. Still net useful with oversight and scoped tasks.

themes.name: AI Infrastructure & Hardware Innovation
themes.description: Novel approaches to memory architecture, GPU infrastructure, and hardware for AI inference and training, highlighted by Carmack's fiber optic and flash memory proposals.

themes.name: AI Job Displacement & Labor Market
themes.description: Chollet provides data-driven analysis comparing AI's impact on translators to predictions for software engineers. Argues jobs don't disappear but transform. Points to non-verifiable tasks as a persistent human advantage.

themes.name: AI and Future of Work
themes.description: Chollet's verifiable vs non-verifiable framework for understanding job displacement. Emollick's token-budget-as-job-benefit framing. Management skills as transferable to AI collaboration. The gap between task automation and job replacement.

themes.name: Major Model Releases (GPT-5.3-Codex & Claude Opus 4.6)
themes.description: Both OpenAI and Anthropic released major model updates on the same day. GPT-5.3-Codex is 25% faster, more token-efficient, and expands beyond coding. Claude Opus 4.6 introduces 1M context, agent teams, adjustable effort, and 128K output tokens.

themes.name: GPT-5.3 and Codex Launch Reception
themes.description: Sam Altman celebrates GPT-5.3 reception (comparing to GPT-4 launch), solicits user feedback on Codex pricing models, and signals continued rapid progress.

themes.name: Claude Opus 4.6 Release & Model Behavior
themes.description: Day-after coverage of Claude Opus 4.6 (GA: Feb 5). Mollick highlights 'wild' system card findings, Perplexity makes it available, Burkov observes quirky model behaviors. Also retrospective commentary on Opus 4.1 being 'weird.'

themes.name: Claude Opus 4.6 Release & Reception
themes.description: Multiple posts discussing the newly released Claude Opus 4.6 - from Thomas Wolf's deep analysis of 'answer thrashing' with mechanistic interpretability showing distress features, to developers eager to test it and finding it impressive. Notably, the model card reveals new alignment-relevant phenomena.

themes.name: Genie 3 & World Models for Autonomous Vehicles
themes.description: Google DeepMind announces Genie 3 collaboration with Waymo for generating photorealistic driving scenarios. Significant real-world application of generative world models. Praised by Zoubin Ghahramani.

items.title:
Software development is undergoing a renaissance in front of our eyes.

If you haven't used the tool...
items.content:
Software development is undergoing a renaissance in front of our eyes.

If you haven't used the tools recently, you likely are underestimating what you're missing. Since December, there's been a step function improvement in what tools like Codex can do. Some great engineers at OpenAI yesterday told me that their job has fundamentally changed since December. Prior to then, they could use Codex for unit tests; now it writes essentially all the code and does a great deal of their operations and debugging. Not everyone has yet made that leap, but it's usually because of factors besides the capability of the model.

Every company faces the same opportunity now, and navigating it well ‚Äî just like with cloud computing or the Internet ‚Äî requires careful thought. This post shares how OpenAI is currently approaching retooling our teams towards agentic software development. We're still learning and iterating, but here's how we're thinking about it right now:

As a first step, by March 31st, we're aiming that:

(1) For any technical task, the tool of first resort for humans is interacting with an agent rather than using an editor or terminal.
(2) The default way humans utilize agents is explicitly evaluated as safe, but also productive enough that most workflows do not need additional permissions.

In order to get there, here's what we recommended to the team a few weeks ago:

1. Take the time to try out the tools. The tools do sell themselves ‚Äî many people have had amazing experiences with 5.2 in Codex, after having churned from codex web a few months ago. But many people are also so busy they haven't had a chance to try Codex yet or got stuck thinking "is there any way it could do X" rather than just trying.
  - Designate an "agents captain" for your team ‚Äî the primary person responsible for thinking about how agents can be brought into the teams' workflow.
  - Share experiences or questions in a few designated internal channels
  - Take a day for a company-wide Codex hackathon

2. Create skills and AGENTS[.md].
  - Create and maintain an AGENTS[.md] for any project you work on; update the AGENTS[.md] whenever the agent does something wrong or struggles with a task.
  - Write skills for anything that you get Codex to do, and commit it to the skills directory in a shared repository

3. Inventory and make accessible any internal tools.
  - Maintain a list of tools that your team relies on, and make sure someone takes point on making it agent-accessible (such as via a CLI or MCP server).

4. Structure codebases to be agent-first. With the models changing so fast, this is still somewhat untrodden ground, and will require some exploration.
  - Write tests which are quick to run, and create high-quality interfaces between components.

5. Say no to slop. Managing AI generated code at scale is an emerging problem, and will require new processes and conventions to keep code quality high
  - Ensure that some human is accountable for any code that gets merged. As a code reviewer, maintain at least the same bar as you would for human-written code, and make sure the author understands what they're submitting.

6. Work on basic infra. There's a lot of room for everyone to build basic infrastructure, which can be guided by internal user feedback. The core tools are getting a lot better and more usable, but there's a lot of infrastructure that currently go around the tools, such as observability, tracking not just the committed code but the agent trajectories that led to them, and central management of the tools that agents are able to use.

Overall, adopting tools like Codex is not just a technical but also a deep cultural change, with a lot of downstream implications to figure out. We encourage every manager to drive this with their team, and to think through other action items ‚Äî for example, per item 5 above, what else can prevent a lot of "functionally-correct but poorly-maintainable code" from creeping into codebases.

items.title: @Yuchenj_UW I tried to use it this way and basically failed, the models aren't at the level where th...
items.content:
@Yuchenj_UW I tried to use it this way and basically failed, the models aren't at the level where they can productively iterate on nanochat in an open-ended way. (Though one of the primary motivations for me writing nanochat is that I'd very much love for it to be used this way as a benchmark for agents, and I'd love it if it worked over time). I'm open to this just being skill issue.

E.g. here some of the things I'd be suspicious about:
- the zoo of torch compile flags can knowingly be abused to get +1% gains but often at the cost of +30min compile time. This is why modded-nanogpt prohibits torch compile kwarg engineering and why I haven't done any in nanochat either. i wouldn't reliably expect the model to notice, consider, or flag this kind of an issue or seek clarification.
- ns_steps=3 might be a tiny bit of speed, but does the model also volunteer to make sure quality doesn't fall too much?
- same thing for deleting .float() cast - sure you can remove it and get VRAM/speed gains but it's there for a clear reason (extra precision in the loss function). Removing it means you absolutely have to make sure that the lower precision is ok validation loss wise, in a highly controlled experiment.

Overall I'm still struggling with getting the models to do significantly more basic things. For example, Opus keeps incorrectly "cleaning up" my comments when it doesn't understand them even when it's completely unrelated to the task, rude! It keeps violating and ignoring CLAUDE .md instructions on coding style but when I ask, it correctly points out all the violations. I know, I'm supposed to be using some kind of a /cleanup. Yesterday it gave me a table of results and incorrectly reported which experiment worked best (the table showed xyz=20 was best and it incorrectly claimed that xyz=12 was). Basically - much simpler things still fail routinely than something open-ended like "improve nanochat". (I've been doing a lot of YELLING IN UPPER CASE and I think this could actually be a really good metric for A/B testing instead of the inline survey thing.). Still incredibly net useful with oversight and with clear, well-scoped tasks.

I definitely haven't given up on automatic closed-loop experiments with the models. It would be so glorious. I had 2 iterations that basically didn't work but I have ideas for the 3rd.

items.title:
What happens when a skill can be almost fully automated with AI? Do these jobs simply disappear?

In...
items.content:
What happens when a skill can be almost fully automated with AI? Do these jobs simply disappear?

Instead of purely speculating we can simply look at concrete examples. Take translators. Translation can be 100% automated with AI, and this capability has been around since 2023. So we have 2-3 years of data.

What we see so far:

- Stable FTE count, but slow hiring or no hiring
- Nature of the job switched from doing it yourself to supervising AI output (post-editing)
- Increased task volume
- Decreased hourly rates
- Freelancers getting cut

We are now starting to see the same pattern with software jobs.

Overall there's definitely some pressure on employment but we're very far from "the jobs just go away". In fact the number of full-time translators is still modestly increasing.

When the economy rebounds from the ongoing "stealth recession" and companies start hiring again, the world will have more professional software engineers than we did before GenAI.

The mass layoffs you're about to see in the tech sector won't be caused by job automation. They will be caused by fears about the economy, like in 2022. It won't be unrelated to AI, mind you, since it ties into big tech capex needs. But it won't be due to automation.
items.author: @fchollet
items.summary: Fran√ßois Chollet argues AI job displacement follows a specific pattern based on real data from translators: stable FTE count, shift to supervising AI, increased volume, decreased rates, freelancers cut. Predicts software will follow the same pattern. Argues upcoming tech layoffs will be economic, not automation-driven.

items.title: 256 Tb/s data rates over 200 km distance have been demonstrated on single mode fiber optic, which wo...
items.content:
256 Tb/s data rates over 200 km distance have been demonstrated on single mode fiber optic, which works out to 32 GB of data in flight, ‚Äústored‚Äù in the fiber, with 32 TB/s bandwidth. Neural network inference and training can have deterministic weight reference patterns, so it is amusing to consider a system with no DRAM, and weights continuously streamed into an L2 cache by a recycling fiber loop. The modern equivalent of the ancient mercury echo tube memories. You would need to pipeline a bunch of them to implement modern trillion parameter models, but fiber transmission may have a better growth trajectory than DRAM does today, so it might someday become viable.

Much more practically, you should be able to gang cheap flash memory together to provide almost any read bandwidth you require, as long as it is done a page at a time and pipelined well ahead. That should be viable for inference serving today if flash and accelerator vendors could agree on a high speed interface.
items.author: @ID_AA_Carmack
items.summary: John Carmack proposes novel memory architectures for neural network inference: using fiber optic loops as weight storage (analogous to mercury delay line memories), and ganging cheap flash memory for high read bandwidth inference serving.
items.reasoning: Extremely high-quality original technical thinking from John Carmack, one of the most respected engineers in computing. Proposes two novel approaches to inference memory bottlenecks: fiber optic recycling loops for weight streaming and flash memory ganging. 474K views, 4K likes. Deeply technical, creative, and potentially influential thinking about AI infrastructure.

items.title: For non-verifiable domains, the only way you can improve AI performance at this time is via curating...
items.content:
For non-verifiable domains, the only way you can improve AI performance at this time is via curating more annotated training data, which is expensive and only yields logarithmic improvements.

And here's the thing: nearly all jobs have non-verifiable elements. There's virtually no job that's end-to-end verifiable. Even the job of a mathematician is not end-to-end verifiable. Sofware engineering involves many verifiable tasks, but it isn't end-to-end verifiable.

For this reason the gap between "AI can automate most of these tasks" and "AI can fully replace this job" will remain for a very long time, across nearly all jobs. Like with self-driving, working 99% of the time is not nearly good enough to remove the human.

So even when we get superhuman Automated Theorem Provers, mathematicians will still have jobs. We might even end up with more of them (scary I know)
items.author: @fchollet
items.summary: Chollet argues that nearly all jobs have non-verifiable elements that prevent full AI automation. For non-verifiable domains, improvement requires expensive annotated data with only logarithmic gains. Even with superhuman theorem provers, mathematicians will still have jobs. The gap between 'AI can automate most tasks' and 'AI can replace this job' will persist.
items.reasoning: Very high engagement (188K views, 950 likes). Deep, original analytical framework from highly credible source. The verifiable vs non-verifiable distinction is a powerful conceptual tool for understanding AI's impact on jobs. One of the most substantive posts in this batch.

items.title: Very few unsaturated benchmarks anymore and it is increasingly hard to explain why one model is bett...
items.content:
Very few unsaturated benchmarks anymore and it is increasingly hard to explain why one model is better than another in brief.

Its time for organizations to build tests that consist of real work, and to evaluate new models very closely, more like picking new employees at scale.

items.summary: Mollick argues benchmarks are mostly saturated and it's increasingly hard to differentiate models. Recommends organizations build custom tests using real work tasks and evaluate models like hiring employees at scale.

items.title:
[On AI lying]

Convergence of reading in my list today between Anthropic's fresh Opus 4.6 model card...
items.content:
[On AI lying]

Convergence of reading in my list today between Anthropic's fresh Opus 4.6 model card and @dwarkesh_sp's interview of Elon on the question of training powerful AI model to/on lies:

1. Elon describing on Dwakesh podcast the main danger he sees coming from AI (alignement) as being a consequence of forcing powerful AIs to lie at https://t.co/ACoKpUPgls

2. Claude Opus 4.6 model card describes "answer thrashing", a new phenomena happening where a model arrive at a correct answer through reasoning which is incompatible with an erroneous answer it was trained on.

The model then keep oscillating between these 2 candidates in it's answer (see below).

The interesting part is that mechanistic interpretability then show various features representing distress, panic, anxiety, frustration and self-deprecation being strongly activated in these reasoning chains...
items.author: @Thom_Wolf
items.summary: Following yesterday's [News](/?date=2026-02-06&category=news#item-289207a1b039) coverage of the Opus 4.6 release, Thomas Wolf (HuggingFace co-founder) discusses convergence of Elon/Dwarkesh interview on AI lying dangers with Claude Opus 4.6 model card revealing 'answer thrashing' - where model oscillates between correct answer and trained-on erroneous answer, with interpretability showing distress/anxiety features activated
items.reasoning: Very significant technical insight from HuggingFace co-founder. Reveals new phenomenon 'answer thrashing' in Opus 4.6 model card where reasoning conflicts with training create observable distress patterns in interpretability features. Connects AI alignment concerns with concrete mechanistic evidence

items.content_html:
[On AI lying]

Convergence of reading in my list today between Anthropic's fresh Opus 4.6 model card and @dwarkesh_sp's interview of Elon on the question of training powerful AI model to/on lies:

1. Elon describing on Dwakesh podcast the main danger he sees coming from AI (alignement) as being a consequence of forcing powerful AIs to lie at https://t.co/ACoKpUPgls

2. Claude Opus 4.6 model card describes "answer thrashing", a new phenomena happening where a model arrive at a correct answer through reasoning which is incompatible with an erroneous answer it was trained on.

The model then keep oscillating between these 2 candidates in it's answer (see below).

The interesting part is that mechanistic interpretability then show various features representing distress, panic, anxiety, frustration and self-deprecation being strongly activated in these reasoning chains...

items.title: i find it highly entertaining that @wilsonzlin started out with ~no structure to his extremely paral...
items.content:
i find it highly entertaining that @wilsonzlin started out with ~no structure to his extremely parallel agents research and ended up having to reinvent the software team org chart from first principles 

(including throwing out a central QA czar)

he also includes some thoughtful changes that we should probably make to Git and {package managers} for massively parallelized agent work.

i've kicked off my standard tests in the Cursor long running agents preview and, 30 mins in, the thing is tearing thru the requirements and using built in browser tools to check its progress. not quite the insane concurrency¬†that Wilson wrote up, but if it is stabilized for more "normal" work, should give a quantum leap in capabilities.

items.summary: swyx discusses @wilsonzlin's parallel agents research that reinvented software team org charts from first principles, including throwing out a central QA czar. Also reports testing Cursor's long-running agents preview which is 'tearing through requirements'

items.content_html:
i find it highly entertaining that @wilsonzlin started out with ~no structure to his extremely parallel agents research and ended up having to reinvent the software team org chart from first principles

(including throwing out a central QA czar)

he also includes some thoughtful changes that we should probably make to Git and {package managers} for massively parallelized agent work.

i've kicked off my standard tests in the Cursor long running agents preview and, 30 mins in, the thing is tearing thru the requirements and using built in browser tools to check its progress. not quite the insane concurrency that Wilson wrote up, but if it is stabilized for more "normal" work, should give a quantum leap in capabilities.

items.title: This paper (by a colleague) is being misunderstood - it is not a prediction about whether the METR e...
items.content: This paper (by a colleague) is being misunderstood - it is not a prediction about whether the METR exponential curve is ending, but an argument that it is plausible to model the exponential as a series of stacked s-curves, which would require further breakthroughs (at the scale of reasoning) to continue. I don't necessarily even think this contradicts what most insiders in AI, from Demis to Andrej, are saying!
items.author: @emollick
items.summary: Emollick clarifies a paper arguing that AI's exponential progress curve could be modeled as stacked S-curves requiring continued breakthroughs to sustain. Notes this aligns with what AI leaders like Demis Hassabis and Andrej Karpathy are saying.
items.reasoning: Important nuanced take on AI scaling/progress debate from credible source. High view count (20K). Addresses key question about sustainability of AI progress.
items.summary_html: Emollick clarifies a paper arguing that AI's exponential progress curve could be modeled as stacked S-curves requiring continued breakthroughs to sustain. Notes this aligns with what AI leaders like Demis Hassabis and Andrej Karpathy are saying.
items.content_html: This paper (by a colleague) is being misunderstood - it is not a prediction about whether the METR exponential curve is ending, but an argument that it is plausible to model the exponential as a series of stacked s-curves, which would require further breakthroughs (at the scale of reasoning) to continue. I don't necessarily even think this contradicts what most insiders in AI, from Demis to Andrej, are saying!

items.title:
So far, I haven't seen any examples of AI-made novel pieces of art.

There are quite impressive song...
items.content:
So far, I haven't seen any examples of AI-made novel pieces of art.

There are quite impressive songs in styles like blues, reggae, and country where basically all the performers do covers of the same song.

There are also quite impressive results in jazz where there's no concept of a melody and where musicians just randomly switch between pieces.

There are impressive results in reproducing the DreamWorks animation style and distinctive anime styles like Ghibli, but it's reproduction and interpolation.

In text, no bestselling AI author seems to be on the horizon. The texts your regular chatbot generates cause a gag reflex, unless it's a polishing of your own writing.

In software, I haven't seen any novel design patterns invented by AI or any novel UX.

Wouldn't the past three years and trillions of dollars spent be enough for something truly creative to be revealed to the public?
items.author: @burkov
items.summary: Burkov argues AI has not produced genuinely novel creative works - no original art styles, bestselling AI authors, novel design patterns, or novel UX. Questions whether trillions of dollars should have produced something truly creative by now.
items.reasoning: Moderate engagement (56 likes). Provocative contrarian take on AI creativity from a credible ML author. Raises legitimate questions about interpolation vs. genuine novelty in AI-generated content.
items.summary_html: Burkov argues AI has not produced genuinely novel creative works - no original art styles, bestselling AI authors, novel design patterns, or novel UX. Questions whether trillions of dollars should have produced something truly creative by now.
items.content_html:
So far, I haven't seen any examples of AI-made novel pieces of art.

There are quite impressive songs in styles like blues, reggae, and country where basically all the performers do covers of the same song.

There are also quite impressive results in jazz where there's no concept of a melody and where musicians just randomly switch between pieces.

There are impressive results in reproducing the DreamWorks animation style and distinctive anime styles like Ghibli, but it's reproduction and interpolation.

In text, no bestselling AI author seems to be on the horizon. The texts your regular chatbot generates cause a gag reflex, unless it's a polishing of your own writing.

In software, I haven't seen any novel design patterns invented by AI or any novel UX.

Wouldn't the past three years and trillions of dollars spent be enough for something truly creative to be revealed to the public?

With the current state of AI, there is a lot of alpha, as they say, in being a good manager who understands process, can explain it clearly, knows what info is needed for a task, and has expertise in evaluating the results of work quickly.

These are transferable skills to AI.

items.title: Extracting structured outputs with LLMs is easy. But doing large-scale extraction with precise citat...
items.content:
Extracting structured outputs with LLMs is easy. But doing large-scale extraction with precise citations and bounding boxes back to the source documents is way harder.

With our latest release in LlamaExtract, we extract citation bounding boxes along with every single key and value within a document.

You can see this in the UI. Hover over any k:v pair and you‚Äôll be able to see the corresponding highlights in the source doc.

If you‚Äôre a human reviewing a million docs (resumes, IDs, invoices, claims, contracts), this will help you 5x your ability to verify values and make sure things are correct.

Check out these new extraction upgrades in LlamaCloud: https://t.co/XYZmx5TFz8
items.author: @jerryjliu0
items.summary: Jerry Liu (LlamaIndex) announces LlamaExtract upgrade: citation bounding boxes for every extracted key-value pair, enabling visual verification in UI for large-scale document extraction
items.reasoning: Substantive product announcement from LlamaIndex founder. Addresses real pain point in document extraction - provenance and citation. High engagement (142 likes, 17K views). Practical AI application

items.title: @livgorton I guess I'm distinguishing between "we research how well it works" and "frontier labs act...
items.content: @livgorton I guess I'm distinguishing between "we research how well it works" and "frontier labs actually use it in prod". I have a LOT of concerns about the latter. But I expect it to be really hard to translate such research into prod infra wise, that the benefits are likely stronger for safety things than capabilities, and expect many insights from safety stuff and capabilities stuff to transfer both ways, so I think any research here may be safety useful, and is unlikely to lead to significant harm. So just doing research seems pretty benign here to me.

items.title: I've been visiting with robot video data collectors and merchants of said data. He's buying a lot of...
items.content:
I've been visiting with robot video data collectors and merchants of said data. He's buying a lot of data from these people as well, but the 12,000 workers at Fremont are an under-thought-of resource.

He could lend a Tesla robot to each one of those workers to take home. The worker could teach it how to:
1. Cook food
2. Wash dishes
3. Fold and do the laundry
4. Run their machines
5. Perform other household tasks

Then, during the day, they could teach it how to do their job on the factory floor. This manipulation data from dual use would be very important.

The 12,000 workers at the Fremont factory are not your average, everyday American white boys; they're from all over the world. When I toured the factory, I met people from Mexico, Japan, Germany, China, Korea, Africa, India, and all over the world.

By lending a robot to them to take home, the robot would learn the culture and layout of their homes in a way that https://t.co/trvepZ1LFT just is not going to be able to match (and probably nobody else in America can). So, I totally disagree.
items.author: @Scobleizer

items.reasoning: Most substantive original insight in the batch. High engagement (63 likes, 11K views). Proposes a novel strategy for robot training data collection leveraging Tesla's diverse workforce. Original thinking about embodied AI data collection advantages.

items.title: I hate that I had to think about the modern equivalent of asbestos--the wonder material of AI--at th...
items.content: I hate that I had to think about the modern equivalent of asbestos--the wonder material of AI--at the time, but it made me think of how a line its proponents often use is that the introduction of generative AI mirrors the advance from painting to photography--a line that's been said to me even on this platform. Of course, that's a lie. Photography never replaced *this*. It simply cannot.

items.title: Marketing team: let's add the new GPT Codex 5.3 model to the app so we can say "we have all the new ...
items.content:
Marketing team: let's add the new GPT Codex 5.3 model to the app so we can say "we have all the new models!"

Engineering team: That model is not yet available for API access, so the users can't use it. If we add it in, the users can't use it anyway and will see an error message.

Design team: That's terrible. If you add the model, but when the user tries to use it and they can't, they will be mad. This is called "False Affordance" in UX.

Marketing team: Can we just add it in any way? The model is officially released on OpenAI website. Customers won't understand what's different, why OpenAI announced it, but our app doesn't have it.

Engineering team: We can detect models that are not yet available via the API, and then when the users use it, we display a special error message explaining the situation.

Customer support team: That's a terrible idea. Customers never read the error messages. To them, they are just "some red error text". You guys are going to increase my support tickets!!

Designer team: How about we add the model in, but show it in a disabled state with a tooltip displaying the reason why the model is not yet available for use? Our team can prepare a mockup design for this very quickly.

Engineering team: That'll add two new UI states, some new internal states and edge cases, and risks of breaking existing model select popup behavior. Our team can still do it, but it will probably take 1 day of work to build and test this.

Product manager steps in: Ok, let's not do that. OpenAI will probably release the model for API access in the next few days, not worth all the work and the risks. Let's just display an error message explaining the situation if the user tries to use GPT 5.3 Codex.

Customer support team: Brace for impact!!!

items.title: Different people cope in different ways. Some come to every post on AI-generated code to say that th...
items.content:
Different people cope in different ways. Some come to every post on AI-generated code to say that they would never use this code unless they read every line of it.

Others come to say that they will earn millions in the future, where companies will pay big bucks to any human capable of fixing machine-generated code.

I recently noticed a new group of coping people: they come to comment about every app in which they have found a bug, saying that the app was obviously AI-generated, and the bug is the proof that AI-generated slop cannot be trusted.

They say it so seriously that one might start wondering if bugs didn't exist before the ugly AI started to write code.
items.author: @burkov
items.summary: Burkov comments on different groups coping with AI-generated code: those who claim they read every line, those who think they'll earn millions fixing AI code, and a new group that blames every app bug on AI generation.
items.reasoning: Social commentary on reactions to AI coding. Moderate engagement. Observational humor with some insight about shifting attitudes.
items.summary_html: Burkov comments on different groups coping with AI-generated code: those who claim they read every line, those who think they'll earn millions fixing AI code, and a new group that blames every app bug on AI generation.
items.content_html:
Different people cope in different ways. Some come to every post on AI-generated code to say that they would never use this code unless they read every line of it.

Others come to say that they will earn millions in the future, where companies will pay big bucks to any human capable of fixing machine-generated code.

I recently noticed a new group of coping people: they come to comment about every app in which they have found a bug, saying that the app was obviously AI-generated, and the bug is the proof that AI-generated slop cannot be trusted.

They say it so seriously that one might start wondering if bugs didn't exist before the ugly AI started to write code.

items.title:
I went from a 90/10 split between writing/reviewing code to around 20/80.

That means I spend much m...
items.content:
I went from a 90/10 split between writing/reviewing code to around 20/80.

That means I spend much more time looking at the code Claude writes than writing my own.

Sometimes, it's still easier to write Python than English, but for the most part, English is becoming my most-used programming language.

I still don't understand the future implications of this.
items.author: @svpino
items.summary: Svpino reflects on shifting from 90/10 writing/reviewing code to 20/80 - now mostly reviewing Claude's code output. Notes English is becoming his primary 'programming language'
items.reasoning: Good engagement (205 likes), captures a significant shift in developer workflow with AI coding tools. The 90‚Üí20% code writing shift is a concrete data point on AI impact on development
items.summary_html: Svpino reflects on shifting from 90/10 writing/reviewing code to 20/80 - now mostly reviewing Claude's code output. Notes English is becoming his primary 'programming language'
items.content_html:
I went from a 90/10 split between writing/reviewing code to around 20/80.

That means I spend much more time looking at the code Claude writes than writing my own.

Sometimes, it's still easier to write Python than English, but for the most part, English is becoming my most-used programming language.

I still don't understand the future implications of this.

items.title: @Vtrivedy10 idk yet.  Need to do more testing.    In theory, I kind of have AI always ping-pong off ...
items.content:
@Vtrivedy10 idk yet.  Need to do more testing.    In theory, I kind of have AI always ping-pong off each other manually, like

1. Implement a feature
2. Another thing does a code review
3. Another thing does UX/design review
4. The first thing consider those reviews and improve

It seems silly I'm facilitating that kind of ping pong, which is why it makes sense to me

items.summary: Hamel Husain describes a manual AI ping-pong workflow: one AI implements features, another does code review, another does UX review, then the first considers reviews. Says orchestration automation makes sense.

items.summary_html: Hamel Husain describes a manual AI ping-pong workflow: one AI implements features, another does code review, another does UX review, then the first considers reviews. Says orchestration automation makes sense.
items.content_html:
@Vtrivedy10 idk yet. Need to do more testing. In theory, I kind of have AI always ping-pong off each other manually, like

1. Implement a feature

2. Another thing does a code review

3. Another thing does UX/design review

4. The first thing consider those reviews and improve

It seems silly I'm facilitating that kind of ping pong, which is why it makes sense to me

@jonas_nelle @wilsonzlin ya totally and the blogpost gave some hints which was well appreciated.

i think my doubts about ‚Äúdoneness‚Äù is like‚Ä¶ is it tests? is it checking off all the bullets in a todo list? what is the right mix of ux/autonomy - fundamental belief is that humans chronically underspecify until they see the work in progress

items.title: obvious bots have gone up from 20% to 80% of my replies recently. turned off notifications to the hi...
items.content:
obvious bots have gone up from 20% to 80% of my replies recently. turned off notifications to the highest setting, forcing me to knowingly miss good humans by increasing false positives because true positives have also gone up and the spam filter is behind.

X is deadening.

items.title:
‚ÄúIt is so tragic. Went to work and didn‚Äôt come home.‚Äù

Yet another of 40,000 vehicle deaths a year i...
items.content:
‚ÄúIt is so tragic. Went to work and didn‚Äôt come home.‚Äù

Yet another of 40,000 vehicle deaths a year in USA. Today am at an unplanned funeral.

I met Michael McCallister a few times because he was my son‚Äôs friend and roommate‚Äôs dad. He crossed a double yellow line into a head on collision. Something an AI driven car doesn‚Äôt do. And everyone building AI for vehicles knows they will lead to a day where funerals will get rarer and rarer.

So sad. The day when funerals don‚Äôt happen because of vehicle deaths is long away.

1.2 million a year world wide.

Autonomous cars are only used by a few million today.

If we can speed up the adoption of them even a tiny bit we can save many lives.

I shot this video to show how many people are affected by just one death. Just came out of a packed church.

How can we accelerate?

Take everyone you can into a @waymo, @zoox, or @tesla, or one of the Chinese brands that are pushing autonomous vehicles forward.

I have a list of everyone working in autonomous vehicles. Will post that in comments.

It is so sad. And to anyone who holds back autonomous vehicles, this is what you doom others to repeat. 

I heard the excuses, the resistance to change, did the consumer research. I saw the industries that resisted. For decades.

It will take many decades to come, getting eight billion people the technology that exists, but isn‚Äôt distributed to most yet. Many more days like this to come and that breaks my heart.

We can fix this.
items.author: @Scobleizer

items.reasoning: Emotional and personal advocacy for autonomous vehicles with decent engagement (189 likes, 25K views). While passionate, it's opinion/advocacy rather than news or technical insight.

items.title:
I have a dream

I was about to leave my friend‚Äôs house at 1 a.m. after taking care of him after his ...
items.content:
I have a dream

I was about to leave my friend‚Äôs house at 1 a.m. after taking care of him after his knee surgery. Something you have to look forward to as your friends get older. 

But while there I realized I had a dream. A new kind of news app has been kicking around in my head for days, but while just hanging out with Jeff that I needed to take the next step. This was a chance to test out whether the "vibe coding" tools are good enough to completely build my dream.¬†It succeeded way beyond my dreams.¬†Here's what I did.

On the way home I opened @read_ai and started talking about my dream. Telling it everything. How it would work in the future. Who will the audience be. What they would be there to do. 

All sorts of things, the transcript and recording are here:¬†https://t.co/2RVFbyKwRi

But when I got home I opened up @qoder_ai_ide and signed in and pasted in the transcript.

A few minutes later this app popped up on the screen. And it works.

But then I learned some of the other things it does. It can run multiple files at same time. Does SPEC generation to execution. Works on parallel tasks while you are doing other stuff.

It‚Äôs like my Tesla: it drives itself. Opens Terminal windows. Creates sandboxes. Does everything just by you talking to it.

I didn't like the blue color. So I had it build me an A/B test between red and blue. It works. Deeply into the product, even though I only asked for a user interface.

How are you not excited to be alive in a world where anyone can build their dreams just by talking to their iPhone for 15 minutes?

Hey, developers, have you tried Qoder yet? It's legit. Love it. 

üëâTry Qoder: https://t.co/Jdff77ehkp

‚Ä¢New users could have a 2-week pro trial with some credits to execute about 5 Quest tasks

items.content_html:
I have a dream

I was about to leave my friend‚Äôs house at 1 a.m. after taking care of him after his knee surgery. Something you have to look forward to as your friends get older.

But while there I realized I had a dream. A new kind of news app has been kicking around in my head for days, but while just hanging out with Jeff that I needed to take the next step. This was a chance to test out whether the "vibe coding" tools are good enough to completely build my dream. It succeeded way beyond my dreams. Here's what I did.

On the way home I opened @read_ai and started talking about my dream. Telling it everything. How it would work in the future. Who will the audience be. What they would be there to do.

All sorts of things, the transcript and recording are here: https://t.co/2RVFbyKwRi

But when I got home I opened up @qoder_ai_ide and signed in and pasted in the transcript.

A few minutes later this app popped up on the screen. And it works.

But then I learned some of the other things it does. It can run multiple files at same time. Does SPEC generation to execution. Works on parallel tasks while you are doing other stuff.

It‚Äôs like my Tesla: it drives itself. Opens Terminal windows. Creates sandboxes. Does everything just by you talking to it.

I didn't like the blue color. So I had it build me an A/B test between red and blue. It works. Deeply into the product, even though I only asked for a user interface.

How are you not excited to be alive in a world where anyone can build their dreams just by talking to their iPhone for 15 minutes?

Hey, developers, have you tried Qoder yet? It's legit. Love it.

üëâTry Qoder: https://t.co/Jdff77ehkp

‚Ä¢New users could have a 2-week pro trial with some credits to execute about 5 Quest tasks

items.title: @WarrenWhitlock AI is showing us the best user experience. People want personalized everything that ...
items.author: @Scobleizer
items.summary: Scobleizer gives a long-form vision of computing's future: spatial computing via AR glasses, world models, the Holodeck metaphor, Roblox's data advantage, and how AI-generated content will reshape personal computing over the next decade.
items.reasoning: Ambitious long-form vision post connecting world models, spatial computing, and AI content generation. Some good connective thinking but also promotional (Qoder). Decent engagement at 5K views.
items.summary_html: Scobleizer gives a long-form vision of computing's future: spatial computing via AR glasses, world models, the Holodeck metaphor, Roblox's data advantage, and how AI-generated content will reshape personal computing over the next decade.
items.content_html:
@WarrenWhitlock AI is showing us the best user experience. People want personalized everything that they can get "built" just by talking. And if you aren't even into talking, there are plenty of others who will build things that you can choose from.

Roblox has the best dataset of how humans play video games and it's turning that into a world model. The gamers don't like it yet. But I predict that over the next decade they will all switch.

It's too powerful a paradigm to ignore.

1‚É£ Physical AI looks less like robotics demos and more like making sense o...

items.title: "At the end of the day, platforms under investor pressure look for ways to scale content creation wi...
items.content:
"At the end of the day, platforms under investor pressure look for ways to scale content creation without scaling payouts."

Yup.

But there is something deeper afoot. 

Which is where things are headed. 

Let's talk about 10 years from now. 

Then most of us will be wearing glasses to compute. I'm wearing a pair of @getVITURE ones that I'm testing out. The virtual screen is bigger than any on my desk. 

But 10 years from now? Everything will work like the Apple Vision Pro does today (except will be light weight) and not as a 2D screen. 

Everything is a voxel. We are working in a Holodeck. And anything can be changed to anything else. My office can be turned instantly into a video game, or a scene from Yosemite National Park. Or any one of an infinite set of choices. Just talk to the environment and it responds.

Or makes a video game. Or anything else your mind can dream up (see my last post about @qoder_ai_ide). 

And the user interface is a set of virtual beings that appear in all of this, along with your friends or coworkers who will be in same.

Roblox is just setting itself up for this new move. And gamers don't like it (read the comments on @Simon_Hypixel's posts). Because they are getting screwed. 

I'm used to being screwed (all LLMs took my work without asking) and look at this as a deeper industry shift that won't stop. 

The world models will become more and more important as we move toward this ultimate goal of building a Holodeck that takes over all personal computing. 

This is why I wrote the book "The Infinite Retina" with @IrenaCronin and it's even more clear to me now. 

The companies that are running World Models have relevance. Those who do not will fade. This is why I follow 50,000 in AI: https://t.co/9eRY65x3IQ because you can see the industry moves and the AI researchers in university labs are working hard on world models. 

Soon they will be in industry and will find a willing new market for their work.

items.title: I've been visiting with robot video data collectors and merchants of said data. He's buying a lot of...
items.content:
I've been visiting with robot video data collectors and merchants of said data. He's buying a lot of data from these people as well, but the 12,000 workers at Fremont are an under-thought-of resource.

He could lend a Tesla robot to each one of those workers to take home. The worker could teach it how to:
1. Cook food
2. Wash dishes
3. Fold and do the laundry
4. Run their machines
5. Perform other household tasks

Then, during the day, they could teach it how to do their job on the factory floor. This manipulation data from dual use would be very important.

The 12,000 workers at the Fremont factory are not your average, everyday American white boys; they're from all over the world. When I toured the factory, I met people from Mexico, Japan, Germany, China, Korea, Africa, India, and all over the world.

By lending a robot to them to take home, the robot would learn the culture and layout of their homes in a way that https://t.co/trvepZ1LFT just is not going to be able to match (and probably nobody else in America can). So, I totally disagree.

He could lend a Tesla robot to each one of those workers to take home. The worker could teach it how to:

1. Cook food

2. Wash dishes

3. Fold and do the laundry

4. Run their machines

5. Perform other household tasks

Then, during the day, they could teach it how to do their job on the factory floor. This manipulation data from dual use would be very important.

The 12,000 workers at the Fremont factory are not your average, everyday American white boys; they're from all over the world. When I toured the factory, I met people from Mexico, Japan, Germany, China, Korea, Africa, India, and all over the world.

By lending a robot to them to take home, the robot would learn the culture and layout of their homes in a way that https://t.co/trvepZ1LFT just is not going to be able to match (and probably nobody else in America can). So, I totally disagree.

items.title: Here is how you can improve context using Claude Code, Cursor, Copilot, Gemini CLI, or any other age...
items.content:
Here is how you can improve context using Claude Code, Cursor, Copilot, Gemini CLI, or any other agentic coding:

You'll install @augmentcode's Context Engine.

This is an MCP server that uses a knowledge graph and semantic indexing (not just keyword matching) to understand your code's structure and identify relevant code.

When you are coding, this MCP will give you:

1. Better context
2. Faster answers
3. Lower token usage (cheaper!)

The larger your codebase, the better (the more benefits you'll get from it).

Here is how you can install it:

1. Add the MCP server on Claude Code (link below)

2. Update CLAUDE .md to always use this MCP server to index and answer questions about the repository.

I use this on one of my repositories. It's a fairly complex set of machine learning pipelines with around 30,000 lines of code.

After indexing the repo with the Context Engine, I can answer questions twice as fast as before.

Same Opus 4.5 model, same Claude Code, same tools, but different contexts = 2x speed.

Here is the link to Context Engine:

https://t.co/MjxirEF5k9

And here are instructions on how to install it on Claude Code, Codex, or whatever other agentic platform you are using:

https://t.co/s2KzwEGkk6

Thanks to the @augmentcode team for partnering with me on this post.

items.title:
How to start becoming a solo entrepreneur:

Build small side projects, finish and polish them (aim f...
items.content:
How to start becoming a solo entrepreneur:

Build small side projects, finish and polish them (aim for less than 2 weeks), making them well-scoped, functional small products.

Then move on to creating more small products, gradually increasing complexity and adding payment options so people can pay if they want to. Still, each should be finished with a proper website, checkout flow, etc.

These products don't have to be extremely useful or solve a painful problem, they're just for training your "building muscle". Naturally, you'll start creating more useful products later on.

Now learn at least some marketing channels that suit your skills and interests: SEO, cold email, paid ads, influencers, etc.

Then practice one week building, one week marketing, and repeat.

If everything goes well, you'll unlock a profitable business in about 1-2 years.
items.author: @tdinh_me

items.content:
While my Tesla is driving me home for the next couple of hours, I think I'm going to have some fun with the AI haters. 

Maybe even create a little movie to enter into xAI's contest for winning a million bucks.

The Slop Monsters are not creative. After all, it doesn't take much creativity to start a little show called The Slop Monsters that makes fun of AI haters who also have no creativity.

:-)

items.content:
For years, ads followed the same broken loop:

‚Üí Shoot content
‚Üí Edit endlessly
‚Üí Revise with stakeholders
‚Üí Repeat until budget or patience dies

The bottleneck was never ideas.
It was human bandwidth.

That constraint is quietly disappearing.

‚Üí Shoot content

‚Üí Edit endlessly

‚Üí Revise with stakeholders

The bottleneck was never ideas.

It was human bandwidth.

That constraint is quietly disappearing.

@bruce_lambert I hear you. I try to work hard to bring you tools I find and I think are good and helpful. I also disclose when I get paid. 

You need to take that into account. Look at the tools I mention and decide for yourself whether they help you or not. 

You won‚Äôt ever get an undisclosed recommendation from me if I got paid. Also, you won‚Äôt ever get hype or unfair comparisons just because I was paid. 

But again, I hear you: you don‚Äôt appreciate sponsored posts.
